Fig. 1 Schematic diagram of fixed bed for the metathesis reaction. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 (a) XRD patterns,(b) 27Al MAS-NMR, (c) N2 adsorption-isotherms and (d) pore size distribution of the MCM-41, 200-MCM-41, 70-MCM-41 and 38-MCM-41 supports. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) NH3-TPD profiles and (b) pyridine IR spectra of the MCM-41, 200-MCM-41, 70-MCM-41 and 38-MCM-41 supports. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) XRD patterns,(b) N2 adsorption-isotherms of the W/MCM-41, W/200-MCM-41, W/70-MCM-41 and W/38-MCM-41 catalysts. (c) EDX-mapping of the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) NH3-TPD profiles and (b) pyridine IR spectra of the W/MCM-41, W/200-MCM-41, W/70-MCM-41 and W/38-MCM-41 catalysts. (Dotted line represents NH3-TPD profile of corresponding supports). Fig. 5 Fig. 6 (a) UV-Vis spectra of the four catalysts. (b) Proposed structure of W species. (c) XPS spectra of the four catalyst. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 (a) H2-TPR profile of the four catalysts. (b) Calculation model of W/MCM-41 and W/MCM-41. (Red ball represents O; white ball represents H; yellow ball represents Si; blue ball represents W; violent ball represents Al) (c) DFT calculation results. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) 1-Butene conversion and (b) propene selectivity of the four catalyst. (Reaction conditions: catalysts was pretreated by N2 at 550 °C for 4 h, 350 °C, WHSV = 0.32). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) 1-Butene conversion and (b) propene selectivity of the yW/70-MCM-41 catalysts with different W metal loading. (Reaction conditions: catalysts was pretreated by N2 at 550 °C for 4 h, 350 °C, WHSV = 0.32) Fig. 9 Fig. 10 (a) 1-Butene conversion and (b) propene selectivity of the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalysts pretreated by different atmosphere. (Reaction conditions: 350 °C, WHSV = 0.32). Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Raman spectra of the MCM-41, 10 W/70-MCM-41 (Air), 10 W/70-MCM-41 (H2) and 10 W/70-MCM-41 (N2) samples. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 (a) 1-Butene conversion and (b) propene selectivity of the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalysts at different temperatures. Graphical Abstract Elucidating the role of support nature of the W catalyst is of great importance for the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene. Herein, a series of highly dispersed W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts were prepared by impregnating W on the Al-MCM-41 supports with different Si/Al ratios. Multi-characterizations together with DFT calculations revealed that the Lewis Acid formed by framework Al could strength the interaction between W metal and Al-MCM-41 support and promote the formation of the W-(O-Si)n species, which are the main active sites in the metathesis reaction. Through the optimization of various parameters (such as Si/Al ratio, W metal loading, pretreatment atmosphere and reaction temperature), optimal 1-butene conversion (94%) and propene selectivity (81%) are obtained on the N2-pretreated 10W/70-MCM-41 catalyst at 350°C under atmospheric pressure. This work may provide some new insights for the rational design of W based catalysts in the olefin metathesis system. Keywords Metathesis 1-Butene Ethylene Lewis Acid MCM-41 1 Introduction The rapid development of propylene downstream applications, such as oxo-alchohols, polypropylene, cumene, acrylonitrile and acrylic acid, results in the surging demand for propylene [1–4]. Traditionally, naphtha steam cracking and heavy oil catalytic cracking are the main processes for propylene production [5]. However, these process units are relatively complex with large production investment, and propylene is not the on-purpose product, which could not satisfy the increasing demand of the market. In this scenario, several on-purpose propylene production technologies, including propane dehydrogenation, methanol to olefins and olefin metathesis [5–8], are being developed commercially to varying degrees. Particularly, incremental improvement of the established olefin metathesis technology is undoubtedly worth considering under the background of emphasizing green and sustainable energy transformation. Generally, heterogeneous catalysts, mainly Re, Mo and W metal supported on SiO2 or Al2O3, could effectively realize the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethylene to propylene [4,9–13]. Although Re-based catalysts with high Re loading (> 10 wt%) exhibit excellent catalytic performance under mild conditions, the high price and easily deactivated characteristics of Re metal increase the operation cost of the process units and limit its further application [14]. On this foundation, Mo and W catalysts have attracted much attention due to the high selectivity and relatively low price [15]. Moreover, W-based catalysts display considerable resistance to poisons, long online lifetime and continuous regeneration without the change of catalyst structure at higher temperature (250-500 °C), resulting in the better catalytic stability compared with Mo-based catalysts [16]. To this point, W-based catalysts still have huge development potential for commercial use. Normally, the content of W oxide, the valence of W species and the support properties are the main factors affecting the catalytic performance of W catalysts [5,15]. Among them, the acid/base property of support is the most critical factor. For the basicity of support, considerable researches have already demonstrated that the addition of alkaline-earth metal (such as Mg and Ca) could inhibit the occurrence of side effects by facilitating the isomerization of 1-butene to 2-butene, which is the most important intermediate in the double decomposition of 1-butene and ethylene [3–4]. Consequently, the only commercialized catalyst for olefin metathesis is the WO3/SiO2 combining with MgO. Nevertheless, for the acidity of support, it is still largely unexplored since the acid property could directly influence the amount and the form of the supported W oxide [10,16]. Harmse et al.[17] compared the catalytic performance of 1-butene metathesis over WO3/SiO2, WO3/SiO2-Al2O3 and WO3/Al2O3 catalysts. They found that the WO3/SiO2-Al2O3 catalyst exhibits high conversion and propylene selectivity. Similarly, Huang et al.[18] observed an improvement of catalytic performance over the mixture of Al2O3-HY support, which could be ascribed to that the incorporation of Brønsted acid could enhance the metal support interaction. Unfortunately, Zhao et al.[19] demonstrated high acidic strength of Bronsted acid could induce the side reactions such as isomerization and polymerization. In addition, Chen et al.[20] reported that both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites could promote the isomerization of 1-butene to 2-butene. Roosmalen et al.[21] proved that the formation of carbenium-ion intermediate is donated by Lewis acid site-alkene complexes (W-O-Si active site). This conclusion was further verified by the work of Wu et al. [22]. Summarily, although it has been widely accepted that little acidity of the support could be beneficial for the metathesis reaction, there is still a lack of systematic and clear study on acidity (especially Lewis acid). Mesoporous zeolites including MCM-41, SBA-15 and KIT-6 have displayed superior features such as high thermal/hydrothermal stability, high degree of structural ordering and tailorable pore size, thus being regarded as an excellent supports for Mo or W in the olefin metathesis reaction [3–4,8,20,23]. For instance, Chen et al. [20] synthesized a series of SBA-15-supported WO3 catalysts by impregnating method. The HSiW-SBA-15 catalyst calcined at 700 °C gave a propene selectivity and a 1-butene conversion of 59.7% and 59.6%, respectively. Wu et al.[22] reports that W − O–Si species of WO3/KIT-6 catalyst are the active site for the olefin metathesis to produce propene at 450 °C. Meanwhile, Bhuiyan et al. [8] compared the catalytic performance of W supported on SBA-15 and MCM-41 supports. The result revealed that the WO3-MCM-41(30) catalyst shows the high activity due to the well-dispersed active tetrahedral tungsten oxide species. Wang et al. [24] also obtained remarkably enhanced performance over the W-MCM-41 catalysts with uniform distribution of W species. These fully indicate that the MCM-41 mesoporous zeolite is an ideal support for loading W to form the recognized W − O–Si activity sites with high metathesis activity. Consequently, the incorporation of appropriate amount Lewis acid to the W/MCM-41 catalyst may promote the metathesis of olefins. To our best knowledge, there is no systematic study on the effect of Lewis acid induced by Al on the metathesis of 1-butene and ethylene in the W/MCM-41 catalysts. In this work, we synthesized a series of W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts with different Si/Al ratios for the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene. The W is uniformly distributed on the Al-MCM-41 support with the enhanced metal-support interaction. Meanwhile, the effect of Si/Al ratio on the catalyst structure and the corresponding catalytic performance was systematically explored. It is found that the Lewis acid formed by framework Al could promote the formation of the W-(O-Si)n group leading to the improvement of overall catalytic performance. Moreover, the effects of various parameters on the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene were also investigated. Ultimately, the plausible metathesis mechanism over the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst was elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Hexadecyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB, ≥99%) and tungsten trioxide (WO3, ≥99%) were provided by Sigma-Aldrichk. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 98%), ammonia solution tetrahydrate (NH3·H2O, 25%-28%), aluminum nitrate (Al(NO3)3·9H2O, ≥99%) and ammonium metatungstate hydrate ((NH4)6H2W12O40·xH2O, 99.5%) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co.,Ltd. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The support of MCM-41 was synthesized by a modified method according to previous literature [25–26]. 2.7 g of CTAB was dissolved in 125 mL of deionized water, stirring at 35 °C (60 r/min). Then 33 mL NH3·H2O was put into the mixture solution, followed by the addition of a certain amount of Al(NO3)3·9H2O.When the Al(NO3)3·9H2O was completely dissolved and the color of the mixture solution became clear, a certain amount of TEOS was added. After stirred for 30 min, the white suspension was transferred into an autoclave and statically heated at 110 °C for 52 h. Finally, the resulting solution was filtered, washed with deionized water at least three times, followed by air-dried at 100 °C and calcined at 550 °C in static air for 6 h to obtain the x-MCM-41 solid materials (38-MCM-41, 70-MCM-41, 200-MCM-41) where x represented the actual molar ratio of Si/Al. The W metal loading of W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts is 4 wt%. The x-W/MCM-41 catalysts were prepared by incipient impregnation method. 1 g x-MCM-41 support was uniformly added into a certain amount of ammonium metatungstate hydrate solution, aging at room temperature for 24 h. Then the mixture was dried and calcined to obtain the W/x-MCM-41 catalysts. The total mass ratio of loaded metals was 4 wt%. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were recorded on an X’Pert PRO MPD diffractometer (PANalytical Corp., Holland) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) to test the phase and crystal structure of materials. Data were obtained by scanning from 0° to 10° (2θ) and from 5° to 60° (2θ). N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were conducted using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The samples were evacuated at 300 °C for 6 h, and then subjected to nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiment at −196 °C. The surface areas of catalysts were calculated using the BET method and the pore size were calculated using the BJH method. The acidity and acid strength of the materials were estimated by the ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) using the Micromeritics Autochem 2910. In a typical process, 0.1 g sample was pretreated at 200 °C in flowing He gas, followed by exposure to NH3 for 1 h. The sample was flushed with He at 50 °C for 1 h to remove the physically adsorbed NH3 and then heated to 600 °C with a heating ramp rate of 10 °C/min. Hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on the Micromeritics Autochem 2910 instrument to analyze the reduction behavior of metals. The consumption of H2 was monitored with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was measured using a Perkin-Elmer PHI ESCA system to determine the composition of surface W species. Pyridine adsorption IR (Py-IR) was used to test the acid types and acidity of zeolite on a NEXUS spectrometer (America). UV-Vis diffuse reflection spectra were collected with a Shimadzu UV-2700 spectrometer to measure the ligands form of W species. Results were recorded over a range of 190-800 nm, and Barium sulfate was used as the baseline reference for all samples. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was used on a STA 449 F5 synchronous thermal analyzer (NETZSC) to determine the amount of carbon deposited on spent catalysts. 8-10 mg of spent sample was heated from ambient temperature to 800 °C(15 °C/min) in flowing air. 2.4 Catalytic test The catalytic reactions of the ethylene and 1-butene were conducted in a fixed-bed microreactor, as shown in Fig. 1 . In a typical reaction process, 1.0 g of W/x-MCM-41 catalyst with a 20-40 mesh size and 1.0 g γ-Al2O3 particles were evenly mixed and placed in a reactor (i.d. 10 mm), followed by another 1.0 g γ-Al2O3 particles were placed at the above layers of reactor for isomerization of 1-butene. All the catalysts were activated at 550 °C for 4 h under N2 stream at a flow rate of 30 mL/min prior to reaction. Then decreasing the reactor temperature to 350 °C, the ethylene and 1-butene were input into it (n(C2H4/1-C4H8) = 1, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) = 0.32 h-1). The all products were analyzed by gas chromatograph, and the propene selectivity were calculated on the basis of 1-butene. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations Dmol3 module of Materials Studio 8.0 was used to do the DFT calculations. The electronic polarization effect was estimated by the double numerical plus polarization (DNP) basis set [27–28]. The meta-generalized gradient approximation (meta-GGA) in the form of the M06-L parameterization was used to describe the potential surface [27,29]. The maximum deviations for gradient, displacement and total energy were 0.002 Ha/Ǻ, 0.005 Ǻ and 1.0 × 10-5 Ha respectively [30]. For the calculation model, it has been proven that a bicyclic model clusters with the 5 and 6 membered rings could represent the MCM-41 mesoporous zeolite. On this foundation, a 14 T zeolite model was constructed. T represents the Si or Al. It should be noted that the Si at the intersection of the 5 and 6 membered rings was replaced by Al to generate the Lewis acid [30]. Single W atom was used as the active component to reveal the metal-support interaction. Similar calculation model has been verified by similar researches. The binding energy was defined by the following equation: E ads =E W+14T -E Mo -E 14T , where E W+14T , E W and E 14T are the total energy of the calculation system, the energy of W atom and the 14 T calculation model, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Al-MCM-41 support The physical structure and properties of MCM-41 support were first investigated. Fig. 2 a shows that there are three diffraction peaks of MCM-41 located at ∼2.4°, ∼3.9° and 4.3°, corresponding to d 100, d 110 and d 200, respectively [25,31]. Obviously, 200-MCM-41, 70-MCM-41 and 38-MCM-41 supports show the small angle diffraction peaks of MCM-41, indicating the formation of the ordered hexagonal pore structure. In addition, the crystallinity of the 70-MCM-41 and 38-MCM-41 supports is lower than that of 200-MCM-41 support, suggesting that the excessive introduction of Al could destroy the pore structure of MCM-41 to some extent. Then, 27Al MAS-NMR was employed to explore the existence form of Al. Fig. 2b shows that 200-MCM-41 and 70-MCM-41 supports have the almost the same characteristic peaks of skeleton aluminum (AlIV) at ∼70 ppm [26,30]. At this time, further introduction of Al makes the 38-MCM-41 support appear two weak peaks of AlV and AlVI (extraframework Al species) [26]. The influence of the framework Al on the pore structure of MCM-41 was further studied by N2 adsorption/desorption. As shown in Fig. 2c-d, a typical type-IV isotherm is observed in all the supports with a narrow pore size distribution of ∼2.3 nm [25]. This indicates that the addition of an appropriate amount of Al (especially the framework Al) could hardly changes the pore structure of MCM-41. The acidity generated by the introduction of Al was further characterized. NH3-TPD was used to determine the strength of the acid sites (Fig. 3 a). It is found that pure silicon MCM-41 support has almost no acidity. The introduction of framework Al on the 200-MCM-41 and 70-MCM-41 supports results in the increase of weak acid (∼180 °C) and strong acid (∼290 °C) simultaneously, and the extraframework Al on the 38-MCM-41 support leads to increase of weak acid content [30]. The types of acid sites was further studied by pyridine IR (Fig. 3b). Commonly, the band at 1540 cm-1 and 1490 cm-1 could be assigned to Brønsted acid and the combination effect of Brønsted acid and Lewis acid, respectively [30]. The bands at 1450 and 1600 cm-1 are belonged to Lewis acidic sites on the samples [31]. Apparently, the four supports only have negligible amount of Brønsted acid sites. The introduction of framework Al does not produce much Brønsted acid is probably due to the amorphous structure of MCM-41 [26, 32]. The introduction of Al mainly increased the Lewis acid sites of the 200-MCM-41, 70-MCM-41 and 38-MCM-41 supports. In addition, Pyridine IR spectra between 1500 cm-1 and 1690 cm-1 could also provide the coordination information of Al species [33]. Figure S1 shows that the MCM-41, 200-MCM-41 and 70-MCM-41 supports almost the same peak intensity of the AlIII, AlIV and AlV, while the 38-MCM-41 support exhibits a very strong AlV peak. This also indicates that the introduction of excessive Al leads to the formation of non-framework aluminum. 3.2 Characterization of W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts Subsequently, W was further impregnated on the Al-MCM-41 supports to obtain the W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts. The dispersion of the supported W species was first explored by XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption and EDX-mapping. Fig. 4 a shows that only one characteristic diffraction peak of SiO2 (located at ∼24°) was observed the W/MCM-41, W/200-MCM-41, W/70-MCM-41 and W/38-MCM-41 catalysts [34]. Although excessive Al could slightly reduce the specific surface area and pore volume of the W/38-MCM-41 catalyst, N2 adsorption-isotherm (Fig. 4a) also shows that the introduction of W does not change the physical structure of the supports. These indicate that the supported W species are uniformly distributed in the supports. To further clarify this point, EDX mapping was performed to observe the distribution of different elements of the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst. Fig. 4c shows that the Al and W elements are well dispersed in the MCM-41 support (containing O and Si elements). This not only confirms the uniform distribution of W species, but also provides strong evidence for the existence of framework Al. Meanwhile, the acidity of W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts was further characterized by NH3-TPD and pyridine IR. Fig. 5 a shows that there are two distinct desorption peaks : the low temperature desorption peak (∼150 °C) and the high temperature desorption peak (300 °C), which correspond to the weak acid position and the medium strong acid position respectively [24]. The result of pyridine IR has demonstrated that Lewis acid is the main acid site in all the catalysts (Fig. 5b). Moreover, the addition of W significantly increased the total weak Lewis acid content of the catalysts in the order of W/38-MCM-41 > W/70-MCM-41 > W/200-MCM-41 > W/MCM-41. It is highly possible that the W could interact with the Al-MCM-41 support with the formation of W-O-Si and W-O-Al species, which are belonged to the weak Lewis acid. Tesonnier et al.[35] found that the introduction of Mo species could reduce the area of strong acid desorption peak of Mo/HZSM-5 catalyst, and then increase the weak acid content induced by extra-framework Al in the aromatization system. Mo and W species have similar chemical properties. Therefore, it is highly possible that the difference of acidity caused by the Si/Al ratios results in the change of binding mode between W species and support surface. Figure S2 shows that the AlIV of the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst displays a certain displacement compared to that of the 70-MCM-41 support, and a small non framework AlVI peak appears in the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst. This indicates that the combination of W species and medium strong Lewis acid sites may result in the removal of framework Al, thus reducing the area of desorption peak at high temperature and increases the area of desorption peak at low temperature. The valence state and existing form of W species are of great importance for the metathesis reaction. To understand the structure of the W species, UV-Vis spectra was performed on the W/MCM-41, W/200-MCM-41, W/70-MCM-41 and W/38-MCM-41 catalysts (Fig. 6 a). Two intense adsorption bands was observed in the range of 190-400 nm. The first peak located at 210 nm and the second peak located at 275 nm could be attributed to the existence of isolated tetracoordinated tungsten oxides [WO4]2-, and the distorted [WO4]2- species interacted with the support, respectively [36–37]. No obvious characteristic peaks of W4+ and W5+ were observed between 400-700 nm [38]. In other words, W species of the four catalysts exist in the form of 6-valent oxides, which is consistent with the conclusion of previous studies [22]. On this basis, we speculate that W6+ species mainly includes three forms in the W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts (Fig. 6b): (I) isolated tungsten oxide (WO3); (II) the active sites of W-O-Si; (III) the active sites of W-O-Al. A more detailed explanation of the W species form was added to the Supporting Information (Figure S3). XPS was further used to analyze the relative content of these three types W6+ species (Fig. 6c). The XPS spectra of W 4f could be deconvolved into two groups of W-(O-W)m and W-(O-Si)n, similar to previously reported on W-modified mesoporous zeolites [22,39–40]. Essentially, type I is attributed to the W-(O-W)m group, and type II and type III belong to the W-(O-Si)n due to their similar framework structure. The incorporation of Al could significantly reduce the ratio of the W-(O-W)m group, and the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst exhibits the highest ratio of the W-(O-Si)n group (64.8%), indicating that Lewis acid (especially the Lewis acid formed by framework Al) could promote the interaction between W and Al-MCM-41 supports with the formation of the W-(O-Si)n group (type II and type III). However, excessive Al results in the decrease of the W-(O-W)m group content (52% in the W/38-MCM-41 catalyst). Combined with the previous characterization results, this is because the weak Lewis acid generated by extra-framework Al prevents W supported onto the Al-MCM-41 in the form of the isolated coordination. It has been demonstrated that the accessible the W-(O-Si)n group (type II and type III) instead of the W-(O-W)m group (type I) serve as the decisive active sites for the metathesis reaction [21]. To further confirm the reliability of XPS, 29Si-NMR was further employed. As shown in Figure S4, there are three peaks located at -90 ppm, -101 ppm and-110 ppm, corresponding to Si-(OH)2(O-Si)3, W-O-Si-(OSi)3 and Si-(O-Si)4, respectively [22]. Peak-fitting results of 29Si-NMR spectra for W/MCM-41, W/200-MCM-41, W/70-MCM-41, W/38-MCM-41 catalysts in Table S1 show that the amount of W-O-Si-(OSi)3 is the highest on the 4 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst, which is consistent with XPS results. Therefore, the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst exhibits superior catalytic performance compared with other catalysts. The interaction between W species and Al-MCM-41 was further studied by H2-TPR and DFT calculation. As shown in Fig. 7 a, there are three H2 consumption peaks in the H2-TPR profile of the four catalysts. The temperatures of the three peaks are 420 °C, 690 °C and 830 °C, corresponding to the reduction process of WO3→WO2.9 →WO2→W [41–42]. It is found that the introduction of Al increased the reduction temperature of the three peaks, suggesting that the existence of Lewis acid could enhance the metal-support interaction making the reduction of W species more difficult. In addition, the temperatures of reduction peaks on the W/38-MCM-41 catalyst are lower than that on the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst [43]. This means that the Lewis acid formed by extra-framework Al could weaken the interaction between metal and supports. To further clarify the binding effect of framework Al on W species, two calculation models (W/MCM-41 and W/Al-MCM-41) were established to carry out DFT calculation (Fig. 7b). Obviously, the Al-MCM-41 support displays higher W binding energy (3.14 eV) than the MCM-41 support (1.31 eV), and more positive charges are obtained on the W surface of the W/Al-MCM-41 model (Fig. 7b). These fully indicate that the Lewis acid formed by framework Al could promote the charge transfer between W and Al-MCM-41, and then enhance the interaction between metal and support. 3.3 Catalytic performance of the W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts with different Si/Al ratios W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts with different Si/Al ratios were evaluated for the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene. Fig. 8 a shows that all the catalysts display relatively high 1-butene conversion (> 90%) in the initial stage (< 2 h). As reaction time was prolonged, the 1-butene conversion decreases due to the deactivation of catalyst caused by coking products gradually covering the active center [10,16,22]. Interestingly, the propene selectivity exhibits a similar trend to that of the 1-butene conversion. It is highly possible that the main active sites could not contact with the reactant with the increase of reaction depth, leading to the occurence of side reactions such as olefin polymerization and self-metathesis reactions. In particular, there is a positive correlation between the catalytic performance and the content of W-(O-Si)n species. According to the characterization results, the Lewis acid produced by framework Al could promote the formation of the W-(O-Si)n species. Thus, the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst has the highest average 1-butene conversion (94.0%) and propene selectivity (74.0%) (Table S2), corresponding to the maximum W-(O-Si)n species (64.8%) (Table S3). This also confirmed that the W-(O-Si)n species (type II and type III) are the real active center for the metathesis reaction, which is in accordance with previous research results. Notably, although the W/38-MCM-41 catalyst possesses a relatively large amount of W-(O-Si)n species (52.0%), it still displays poor catalytic performance and the fastest catalyst deactivation rate (Fig. 8). This may be caused by two reasons: (1) the introduction of excessive Al leads to the collapse of part of the pore structure of MCM-41 (Table S4) and (2) the Lewis acid formed by extra-framework Al prevents the exposure of the accessible W-(O-Si)n active sites. Therefore, it can be concluded that Lewis acid produced by framework Al contributes to the improvement of overall catalytic performance, while Lewis acid formed by extra-framework inhibits the occurrence of metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene. 3.4 Optimization of the W metal loading on the 70-MCM-41 support The W metal loading was further optimized on the 70-MCM-41 support. Detailed characterizations of the yW/70-MCM-41 catalysts were provided in the Figure S5-S7 and Table S5-S6. Briefly, the crystal diffraction peak (33°) of WO3 and UV absorption peak (400 nm) of W4+ or W5+ could only be observed when the metal loading is higher than 10% (Figure S5 and Figure S7). Meanwhile, the increase of W loading does not block the pore structure of the 70-MCM-41 support and change the properties and strength of Lewis acid of the catalysts (Table S5 and Figure S6). It should be noted that the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst exhibits the strongest intensity for the Lewis acid with the highest W-(O-Si)n species (74.7%) (Table S6), resulting in the excellent catalytic performance for the metathesis reaction (94% 1-butene conversion and 81% propene selectivity in 1 h). In addition, MCM-41 support and Al2O3 also display approximately 80% conversion of 1-butene and 10% propene selectivity since the loading of γ-Al2O3 particles in the reactor bed and the few acidity of SiO2 itself could induce the occurence of the 1-butene isomerization. With the increase of W loading, both 1-butene conversion and propene selectivity increase rapidly. However, excessive supported W could inhibit the improvement of catalytic performance due to the increase of isolated WO3 species. Consequently, the optimal W metal loading on the 70-MCM-41 was 10 wt%. (Fig. 9 ) 3.5 The effect of pretreatment gas atmosphere and reaction temperature Generally, the catalyst for the olefin metathesis reaction must be pretreated at high temperature to achieve excellent catalytic performance [44–45]. Fig. 10 shows the evaluation results on the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst under the pretreatment atmosphere of Air, 10%H2+90%N2 and N2. The catalysts pretreated in three atmospheres exhibit high 1-butene conversion and propene selectivity in the first hour. With the extension of the reaction time, the catalytic performance decreased gradually. The N2-pretreated catalyst shows the best catalytic stability, followed by the 10%H2+90%N2-pretreated and H2-pretreated catalysts. This is probably due to the fact that N2 at high temperature could dredge the pore structure of Al-MCM-41 and promote the activation of the W-(O-Si)n species in advance, while the air atmosphere plays a completely opposite role [44–45]. For the 10%H2+90%N2-pretreated catalyst, the defect sites caused by high temperature are easily saturated by H2 limiting the further improvement of the catalytic performance. To further understand the differences in catalytic performance, XPS, chemisorption and Raman spectra of the catalysts pretreated in different atmospheres were supplemented in the revised manuscript (Figure S8-S12 and Table S7-S8). It should be noted that the XPS spectrum of the air pre-treated catalyst is the fresh 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst. As shown in Figure S8, the amount of W-(O-Si)n species was 83.6% after N2 treatment and 77.8% after H2 pretreatment (Table S7). It indicates that after pretreatment in N2, supported WO3 could interact with the Al-MCM-41 support to form more W-(O-Si)n species. However, in the high temperature H2 atmosphere, the surface W-(O-Si)n species could be saturated. H2-TPR profile of the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst clearly shows that the possible active species are reduced (Figure S9). In addition, due to the oxidizability of air, W-(O-Si)n species species on the catalyst could aggregate to form WO3, resulting in the lowest content of the W-(O-Si)n species. To further confirm the existence of W-O-Si-(OSi)3 species, Raman spectra of the MCM-41, 10 W/70-MCM-41 (Air), 10 W/70-MCM-41 (H2) and 10 W/70-MCM-41 (N2) samples were further investigated. Fig. 11 shows that the loading of W could significantly affect the Raman shift. The 10 W/70-MCM-41 (H2) and 10 W/70-MCM-41 (N2) samples exhibit the spectral peaks belonging to octahedral WO3 species at 270 cm-1 (symmetric tensile vibration of W-O bond), 713 cm-1 (bending vibration of W-O bond) and 805 cm-1 (deformation vibration of W-O-W) and surface isolated tetrahedral species at 960 cm-1 (asymmetric stretching or symmetric stretching vibration of W = O bond) [46–48]. This is consistent with the conclusion of XPS that the 10 W/70-MCM-41 (N2) catalyst (83.6%) has more active sites (W-O-Si-(OSi)3 species) than the 10 W/70-MCM-41 (H2) catalyst (77.8%). In contrast, all the peak intensity of W species of the 10 W/70-MCM-41 (Air) catalyst is greatly reduced, indicating the fewer target active sites (W-O-Si-(OSi)3 species). Meanwhile, the used catalysts pretreated in different atmospheres were characterized by pyridine IR, NH3-TPD and XPS to further understand the underlying reasons for the difference on catalytic stability. Figure S10 shows that the used 10 W/70-MCM-41 (N2) catalyst still has a lot of acidic sites (mainly in the form of Lewis acid). Moreover, the W-(O-Si)n species of the catalysts treated with nitrogen, air and hydrogen atmosphere were 70.6%, 66.2% and 62.6%, respectively (Figure S11 and Table S8). Consequently, the 10 W/70-MCM-41 (N2) catalyst with the abundant W-(O-Si)n species and acidic sites exhibits the good catalytic stability. The effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst was further studied. It is found that the high 1-butene conversion could be obtained on the catalyst (>90%) when the temperature is higher than 250 °C (Fig. 12 a-b). However, much higher temperature (400 °C) leads to the decrease of propene selectivity. The used catalysts at different temperature were further characterized by UV-Vis (Fig. 12c). Fig. 11c shows that the absorption peak of W4+ or W5+ appears at 400 nm on the used catalyst (250 °C), suggesting that the reaction temperature could not facilitate enough W-(O-Si)n species for the metathesis reaction. Meanwhile, the high reaction temperature (400 °C) weakens the absorption peak of W-(O-Si)n species, leading to the deactivation of the catalyst. TG profiles show that the quality change of the used catalyst (400 °C) is the largest, confirming the occurrence of serious coking reaction (Fig. 12d). Therefore, the optimum reaction temperature for the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst under N2-pretreated atmosphere is 350 °C. Given our interest in the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene, we compared the catalytic performance of the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst with previously reported catalysts (Table S9). The 8 wt%WO3/SiO2 catalyst displays the highest propene selectivity (86%) due to the high reaction pressure [49]. In comparison, the 1-butene conversion (94%) and propene selectivity (81%) of our 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst are at the leading level in W-based catalysts. 3.6 Plausible reaction pathways Finally, the plausible reaction mechanism over the 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst is summarized in the Fig. 13 . For the formation of propene, 1-butene first needs to be isomerized to form 2-butylene, then the ethylene and 2-butylene could interact with the W-(O-Si)n species to generate the carbene intermediates, resulting in the formation of propene product. The introduction of Lewis acid strengths the interaction between metal and support and promote the formation of the W-(O-Si)n species, thus enhancing the catalytic activity and selectivity. Due to the instability of olefins at high temperature, side reactions such as polymerization could occur, and the as-formed coke products may cause the deactivation of catalyst surface. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, we prepared a series of highly dispersed W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts by impregnating W on the Al-MCM-41 supports with different Si/Al ratios, and their catalytic performances for the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethylene to propene are evaluated. The results show that the Si/Al ratio could significantly affect the 1-butene conversion and propene selectivity. The excellent catalytic performance of the W/70-MCM-41 catalyst with the highest framework Al content is attributed to the maximum W-(O-Si)n species and the enhanced metal-support interaction. Through further optimization of the W metal loading, pretreatment atmosphere and reaction temperature, 94% 1-butene conversion together with 81% propene selectivity could be obtained on the N2-pretreated 10 W/70-MCM-41 catalyst at 350 °C under atmospheric pressure. coredata.dc:description: Elucidating the role of support nature of the W catalyst is of great importance for the metathesis reaction of 1-butene and ethene to propene. Herein, a series of highly dispersed W/Al-MCM-41 catalysts were prepared by impregnating W on the Al-MCM-41 supports with different Si/Al ratios. Multi-characterizations together with DFT calculations revealed that the Lewis Acid formed by framework Al could strength the interaction between W metal and Al-MCM-41 support and promote the formation of the W-(O-Si)n species, which are the main active sites in the metathesis reaction. Through the optimization of various parameters (such as Si/Al ratio, W metal loading, pretreatment atmosphere and reaction temperature), optimal 1-butene conversion (94%) and propene selectivity (81%) are obtained on the N2-pretreated 10W/70-MCM-41 catalyst at 350°C under atmospheric pressure. This work may provide some new insights for the rational design of W based catalysts in the olefin metathesis system.
coredata.dc:title: Insight into the Effect of Lewis Acid of W/Al-MCM-41 Catalyst on Metathesis of 1-Butene and Ethylene
